qas.question: Which Scottish theologian is first credited with using the phrase "rule of law"?
Which British jurist later made the phrase "rule of law" popular in the 1800s?
What phrase Ariostle also use which is closely related to "the rule of law"?
Samuel Rutherford used the principle of the rule of law to argue what point?

answers.text: against the divine right of kings

qas.question: According to the rule of law, what should hold the determination for rules in a land?
What type of rule says a nation should be governed by the decisions of government officials?
What refers to the influence and authority of society?
What country can a phrase rule of law be traced back to the 1600s?
What British theologian used the rule of law in his argument against the divine rights of kings?
What jurist popularized the phrase rule of law in the 1900s?

context: The <b5_0><b6_0>rule of law<b6_0/><b5_0/> is the legal principle that <a4_0>law<a4_0/> should govern a nation, as opposed to being governed by arbitrary decisions of individual government officials. It primarily refers to the influence and authority of law within society, particularly as a constraint upon behaviour, including behaviour of government officials. The phrase can be traced back to 16th century <b7_0>Britain<b7_0/>, and in the following century the Scottish theologian <a0_0><b8_0>Samuel Rutherford<b8_0/><a0_0/> used the phrase in his argument <a3_0>against the divine right of kings<a3_0/>. The rule of law was further popularized in the 19th century by British jurist <a1_0><b9_0>A. V. Dicey<b9_0/><a1_0/>. The concept, if not the phrase, was familiar to ancient philosophers such as Aristotle, who wrote "<a2_0>Law should govern<a2_0/>".
